title: QOTD: What Does a Trump Win Mean For Tesla?
description: We'll be poking around the issue ourselves, and perhaps writing about it -- but I also wanted to pick your brains. What does the Trump victory mean for Tesla? And, perhaps, Tesla's competitors?
author: Tim Healey
excerpt: We'll be poking around the issue ourselves, and perhaps writing about it -- but I also wanted to pick your brains.What does the Trump victory mean for Tesla?And, perhaps, Tesla's competitors?
text: Published:  November 6th, 2024 We'll be poking around the issue ourselves, and perhaps writing about it -- but I also wanted to pick your brains. What does the Trump victory mean for Tesla?And, perhaps, Tesla's competitors? We all know that Tesla boss Elon Musk is buddy-buddy with Trump -- but we also know that Trump has pushed back on the growth of electric vehicles as an option. Tesla, of course, sells only EVs.There are larger market forces to be explored here -- does Musk, for example, convince Trump to become more pro-EV? -- but let's focus on Tesla for today. Will the brand get a sort of "favored nation" status within the administration? Will it get an unfair and/or illegal advantage over competitors? Or will very little of consequence happen?Perhaps something in the middle?Again, it's a political QOTD at a fraught time. People are emotional about politics right now, even more so than usual. So please play nice below or face the banhammer.With that in mind, sound off below.[Image: Jonah Elkowitz/Shutterstock.com]Become a TTAC insider. Get the latest news, features, TTAC takes, and everything else that gets to the truth about cars first by  subscribing to our newsletter. Tim Healey Tim Healey grew up around the auto-parts business and has always had a love for cars — his parents joke his first word was “‘Vette”. Despite this, he wanted to pursue a career in sports writing but he ended up falling semi-accidentally into the automotive-journalism industry, first at Consumer Guide Automotive and later at Web2Carz.com. He also worked as an industry analyst at Mintel Group and freelanced for About.com, CarFax, Vehix.com, High Gear Media, Torque News, FutureCar.com, Cars.com, among others, and of course Vertical Scope sites such as AutoGuide.com, Off-Road.com, and HybridCars.com. He’s an urbanite and as such, doesn’t need a daily driver, but if he had one, it would be compact, sporty, and have a manual transmission. More by Tim Healey Published November 6th, 2024 6:00 PM Comments Join the conversation Elon will gorge on government contracts for a while, which will help everyone (especially the banks) forget about the financial black hole that was the Twitter acquisition. Tesla will sell lots of cars to Trumpists, which may actually be helpful in teaching them that EVs are usable in many use cases. Then for whatever reason Trump will get pissed off at Elon and he will suffer the same fate as everyone else who has ever worked for Trump. Suddenly Tesla cars will be "terrible" and Tesla will be "failing," SpaceX will lose a lot of contracts, and Elon will lose many billions in market cap. Jmo2 13 minutes ago It’s amazing to watch Teslas move from left coded to right coded in real time. Just you watch as the usual suspects change their tune.
html:
Published:  November 6th, 2024

We'll be poking around the issue ourselves, and perhaps writing about it -- but I also wanted to pick your brains. What does the Trump victory mean for Tesla?

And, perhaps, Tesla's competitors?

We all know that Tesla boss Elon Musk is buddy-buddy with Trump -- but we also know that Trump has pushed back on the growth of electric vehicles as an option. Tesla, of course, sells only EVs.

There are larger market forces to be explored here -- does Musk, for example, convince Trump to become more pro-EV? -- but let's focus on Tesla for today.

Will the brand get a sort of "favored nation" status within the administration? Will it get an unfair and/or illegal advantage over competitors? Or will very little of consequence happen?

Perhaps something in the middle?

Again, it's a political QOTD at a fraught time. People are emotional about politics right now, even more so than usual. So please play nice below or face the banhammer.

With that in mind, sound off below.

[Image: Jonah Elkowitz/Shutterstock.com]

Become a TTAC insider. Get the latest news, features, TTAC takes, and everything else that gets to the truth about cars first by  subscribing to our newsletter.

Tim Healey

Tim Healey grew up around the auto-parts business and has always had a love for cars — his parents joke his first word was “‘Vette”. Despite this, he wanted to pursue a career in sports writing but he ended up falling semi-accidentally into the automotive-journalism industry, first at Consumer Guide Automotive and later at Web2Carz.com. He also worked as an industry analyst at Mintel Group and freelanced for About.com, CarFax, Vehix.com, High Gear Media, Torque News, FutureCar.com, Cars.com, among others, and of course Vertical Scope sites such as AutoGuide.com, Off-Road.com, and HybridCars.com. He’s an urbanite and as such, doesn’t need a daily driver, but if he had one, it would be compact, sporty, and have a manual transmission.

More by Tim Healey

Published

November 6th, 2024 6:00 PM

Comments
Join the conversation

  • Elon will gorge on government contracts for a while, which will help everyone (especially the banks) forget about the financial black hole that was the Twitter acquisition. Tesla will sell lots of cars to Trumpists, which may actually be helpful in teaching them that EVs are usable in many use cases. Then for whatever reason Trump will get pissed off at Elon and he will suffer the same fate as everyone else who has ever worked for Trump. Suddenly Tesla cars will be "terrible" and Tesla will be "failing," SpaceX will lose a lot of contracts, and Elon will lose many billions in market cap.

  • Jmo2 13 minutes ago

    It’s amazing to watch Teslas move from left coded to right coded in real time. Just you watch as the usual suspects change their tune.
